Award.AwardTitle: Additive Manufacturing of Near-Net Shape and Fully Dense Shape Memory Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the study of a novel laser-based additive manufacturing technique to fabricate materials with unique ability to return to its original shape after severe deformation, referred to as shape memory alloys. Two primary objectives are to develop a fundamental understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property relationships and to tailor the underlying microstructural morphology and thus the shape memory material response. Parts are built-up as successive metallic powder layers are deposited and laser consolidated. For the alloys, temperature or external force/stress facilitates an atomic structure change that begets a solid-solid microstructure phase transformation. By reversing the sense of external stimuli (heating/cooling or loading/unloading) after deformation, the transformation happens in reverse and the bulk material recovers its original shape. Small-scale shape memory alloy plate and rod geometries will be synthesized using additive manufacturing. This work characterizes both the thermal-induced and stress-induced phase transformations as well as underlying atomic-/microstructure using transmission electron microscopy. The evolution of the transformation during deformation is visualized by combining temperature cycling and mechanical stressing experiments with real-time micro-scale measurements of localized displacement/strain and temperature.

The additive manufacturing technique builds 3-D computer generated model geometries layer-by-layer in a cost-effective, energy efficient, and environmental conscious manner. The materials design aspect of this fundamental study takes advantage of the capabilities of the technique for parallel processing of diverse powder mixtures and parallel synthesis with variable processing parameters. This will determine fundamental relationships between processing parameters, microstructure, and shape memory behavior. Additive manufacturing offers a novel approach to commercially manufacture near-net shape constructs. The work is the foundation for geometrically complex hierarchical structures - micrometer scale plate and rod geometries are structural building blocks. Shape memory alloy hierarchical structures are promising for practical applications including earthquake and impact mitigation and vibration damping for civil, naval, automotive, and aerospace structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the study of a novel laser-based additive manufacturing technique to fabricate materials with unique ability to return to its original shape after severe deformation, referred to as shape memory alloys. Additive manufacturing provides an attractive alternative for fabrication of shape memory alloys.   Unfortunately, due to the unique mechanical properties of SMAs, traditional machining processes are extremely difficult if not impossible. As a result, virtually all Nitinol (NiTi) components are fabricated through a similar series of basic steps to produce shapes such as wires, tubes, sheets and bars from which final products are made.  AM provides an attractive alternative for fabrication of SMAs, creating devices that have shape memory properties in one section and superelastic properties in another section of the same continuous part.   

The research project demonstrated the potential for the deposition of NiTi SMAs using a laser-based directed energy deposition (DED) additive manufacturing (AM).  The primary objectives developed a fundamental understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property relationships and to tailor the underlying microstructural morphology and thus the shape memory material response. Parts were built-up as successive metallic powder layers are deposited and laser consolidated.  For the alloys, temperature or external force/stress facilitates an atomic structure change that begets a solid-solid microstructure phase transformation.  By reversing the sense of external stimuli (heating/cooling or loading/unloading) after deformation, the transformation happens in reverse and the bulk material recovers its original shape. 

Thin-walled structures were fabricated from multiple passes and layers in order to glean fundamental understandings. This step is critical to characterizing the ability to use AM to fabricate complex hierarchal structures., which will require the fabrication of a large number of inter-connected layers. As a result, it is critical to understand the impact of the deposition of multiple layers into even a large simple geometry is critical.   For example, each location in the build will experience complex thermal cycles, which include a wide range of thermal excursions that will lead to phase transformations and grain growth. In addition to the impact of these thermal cycles, dilution between adjacent layers, altering the local alloy compositions, along with vaporization of alloying elements must be taken into account.  

Full-field deformation measurements, calculated using the digital image correlation technique, were employed to scrutinize the underlying shape memory phase transformation. The results are an initial step to provide a fundamental understanding of the reversible manner of the microstructure transition.  The relationship between microstructural anisotropy and superelasticity in large builds fabricated using directed energy deposition additive manufacturing was investigated. By using elementally blended Ni and Ti powders, the feedstock composition was tailored to obtain Ni-rich build coupons for which superelasticity is expected. Ni4Ti3 precipitates were observed in the as-deposited materials, even though they are typically observed only after an aging heat treatment of Ni-rich NiTi SMAs. This work is the first to report on the consequences of anisotropic microstructures on the spatial resolution of superelastic behavior, using full-field deformation measurements to correlate the underlying SIMT to the anisotropic microstructure. 

The research extended the utilization of AM to multifunctional materials and advanced a novel fabrication technique for shape memory alloys.  The award supported two Ph.D. students (including 1 female) and 3 undergraduate research assistants (including 1 female).  The wor...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This award supported the study of a novel laser-based additive manufacturing technique to fabricate materials with unique ability to return to its original shape after severe deformation, referred to as shape memory alloys. Additive manufacturing provides an attractive alternative for fabrication of shape memory alloys. Unfortunately, due to the unique mechanical properties of SMAs, traditional machining processes are extremely difficult if not impossible. As a result, virtually all Nitinol (NiTi) components are fabricated through a similar series of basic steps to produce shapes such as wires, tubes, sheets and bars from which final products are made. AM provides an attractive alternative for fabrication of SMAs, creating devices that have shape memory properties in one section and superelastic properties in another section of the same continuous part. The research project demonstrated the potential for the deposition of NiTi SMAs using a laser-based directed energy deposition (DED) additive manufacturing (AM). The primary objectives developed a fundamental understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property relationships and to tailor the underlying microstructural morphology and thus the shape memory material response. Parts were built-up as successive metallic powder layers are deposited and laser consolidated. For the alloys, temperature or external force/stress facilitates an atomic structure change that begets a solid-solid microstructure phase transformation. By reversing the sense of external stimuli (heating/cooling or loading/unloading) after deformation, the transformation happens in reverse and the bulk material recovers its original shape. Thin-walled structures were fabricated from multiple passes and layers in order to glean fundamental understandings. This step is critical to characterizing the ability to use AM to fabricate complex hierarchal structures., which will require the fabrication of a large number of inter-connected layers. As a result, it is critical to understand the impact of the deposition of multiple layers into even a large simple geometry is critical. For example, each location in the build will experience complex thermal cycles, which include a wide range of thermal excursions that will lead to phase transformations and grain growth. In addition to the impact of these thermal cycles, dilution between adjacent layers, altering the local alloy compositions, along with vaporization of alloying elements must be taken into account. Full-field deformation measurements, calculated using the digital image correlation technique, were employed to scrutinize the underlying shape memory phase transformation. The results are an initial step to provide a fundamental understanding of the reversible manner of the microstructure transition. The relationship between microstructural anisotropy and superelasticity in large builds fabricated using directed energy deposition additive manufacturing was investigated. By using elementally blended Ni and Ti powders, the feedstock composition was tailored to obtain Ni-rich build coupons for which superelasticity is expected. Ni4Ti3 precipitates were observed in the as-deposited materials, even though they are typically observed only after an aging heat treatment of Ni-rich NiTi SMAs. This work is the first to report on the consequences of anisotropic microstructures on the spatial resolution of superelastic behavior, using full-field deformation measurements to correlate the underlying SIMT to the anisotropic microstructure. The research extended the utilization of AM to multifunctional materials and advanced a novel fabrication technique for shape memory alloys. The award supported two Ph.D. students (including 1 female) and 3 undergraduate research assistants (including 1 female).
